{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox video game | title = Mugsy's Revenge | developer = [[William Tang (video game designer)|William Tang]], Neil Brennan, Russell Comte, David O'Callaghan, Mike Robinson, Michael Gilmour | publisher = [[Krome Studios Melbourne|Melbourne House]] | designer = | released = [[1986 in video gaming|1986]] | genre = [[Strategy and Management]] | modes = [[Single player]] | platforms = [[ZX Spectrum]], [[Commodore 64]], [[Amstrad CPC]]}}
'''''Mugsy's Revenge''''' is a strategy and management [[computer game]] for the ZX Spectrum, Commodore 64 and Amstrad CPC that was released in 1986. It is effectively a sequel to the earlier '[[Mugsy (video game)|Mugsy]]' by the same publisher, and has many of the same features, in both design, and setting.
== Gameplay ==
The player takes the role of 'Mugsy', a gangster who has just been released from prison. The game begins in 1919, and the aim of the game is for Mugsy to make a fortune from the [[rum-running|bootleg]] smuggling business, which has been generated as a result of [[prohibition]]. In each 'turn' of the game, which represents one year, decisions must be made about how much illegal alcohol to buy, which staff to assign to which activity, and how much money to spend on bribing law enforcement. Surviving for ten years means that the game ends, with the repeal of prohibition.
The game had a similar theme and visual style to 'Mugsy', in that it featured strong, colorful graphics in a similar style to [[comic books]], with information presented to the player in the form of dialogue between on-screen characters, such as Mugsy himself, and an un-named assistant. At each decision point, the player enters text into a dialogue box.
There was also a [[mini-game]] arcade element. This is triggered in the event that one of Mugsy's rivals orders a [[contract killing]] on him. When this happens, the player controls Mugsy directly, and must shoot the assassins who are sent after him before he being shot too many times himself.
==Controls==
Only a keyboard could be used for the majority of the gameplay, since most of the user input was by text. A joystick could be used for the arcade sequence.
==Release==
The game was released at a price of £8.95 for the Commodore and Amstrad versions, and £7.95 for the Spectrum.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldofspectrum.org/pub/sinclair/games-adverts/m/MugsysRevenge.jpg|accessdate=25 June 2015|title=Mugsy's Revenge Advertisement|publisher=Melbourne House}}</ref>
== Reception ==
Reviews of the Spectrum edition were generally warm, and many compared it unfavourably to the original Mugsy. While many reviews were positive about the graphics, gameplay was seen as repetitive. Scores out of ten from magazines were 7 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ysrnry.co.uk/articles/mugsysrevenge.htm|title=Mugsy's Revenge|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref> ([[Your Sinclair]]) 6 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zxspectrumreviews.co.uk/review.aspx?gid=3740&rid=6142|title=Sinclair ZX Spectrum Reviews|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref> ([[Crash (magazine)|Crash]]) and 8 from [[Sinclair User]].
The Commodore reviews were less positive, ranging from 2 out of 10 from [[Your Commodore]], to 6 out of 10 in [[Computer and Video Games]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemon64.com/?mainurl=http%3A//www.lemon64.com/games/details.php%3FID%3D1747|title=Lemon - Commodore 64, C64 Games, Reviews & Music!|work=Lemon64|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref>

Ltd) | foundation = [[Osaka]], Japan (1981) | location = Osaka, Japan | industry = Language instruction | revenue = {{nowrap|{{loss}} 57,064 million [[Japanese Yen|JPY]] (2007){{cite web| url = http://www.jasdaq.co.jp/ir/show.do?lang=E&stock=JP3760300008| title = Consolidated Financials| accessdate =5 June 2007| year = 2007 | work = Jasdaq Interim and Consolidated Performance Figures| publisher = JASDAQ Securities}}}} | net_income = {{loss}} −2,495 million JPY (2007) | key_people = [[Nozomu Sahashi]] (founder, former CEO)
[[Masaki Inayoshi]] (former owner) | homepage = {{URL|http://www.nova.co.jp}} }} '''Nova''' (formerly '''Nova Group''') is a large [[eikaiwa school]] (private [[English (language)|English]] [[language education|teaching company]]) in Japan. It was by far the largest {{cite web |url=http://www.nova.ne.jp/english/corporation/05gaiyou/marketshare.html |title=Nova Market Share |accessdate=21 March 2007 |publisher=Japan Ministry of Economy via Nova Corp Website |date=2002–2003 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5aHdaYReV?url=http://www.nova.ne.jp/english/corporation/05gaiyou/marketshare.html |archivedate=23 August 2008 |df=dmy }} company of this type until its widely publicized collapse in October 2007. Before its [[bankruptcy]], Nova employed approximately 15,000 people across a group of companies that supported the operations of and extended out from the "Intercultural Network" of its language schools. The scope of its business operations reached its peak in February 2007 following a rapid expansion of its chain to 924 Nova branches plus a Multimedia Center located in [[Osaka]]. Nova, known for high-priced lesson packages, {{cite web |url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/420857 |title=Stranded foreign teachers left penniless after Nova's fall |accessdate=31 October 2007 |publisher=[[Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry|METI]] |date=31 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5SzdzWNWF?url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/420857 |archivedate=31 October 2007 |df=dmy }} and later plagued by lawsuits and negative publicity, began to decline in earnest almost immediately after the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry placed a six-month ban against soliciting new long-term contracts from students on the company on 13 June 2007. {{cite web |url= http://www.meti.go.jp/press/20070613004/tokutei_press.pdf |format=PDF|title= METI Report on Nova |accessdate=29 September 2007 |publisher= METI |date= 13 June 2007 }} The impending financial crisis facing Nova related to a rapid increase in refund claims, significant drops in sales figures, and deterioration of its reputation, came to the fore in September 2007 when Nova began to delay payment of wages and [[Performance-related pay|bonuses]] to staff. The [[National Union of General Workers|NAMBU Foreign Workers Caucus]] in Tokyo estimated that up to 3,000 staff had not received their salaries on time. A solution for Nova's failure to pay wages was promised by 19 October in a fax sent to branch schools. On 23 October the Osaka Labor Standards office accepted a demand by [[Trade union|unionized]] Nova instructors to investigate criminal charges against Nova President and founder, [[Nozomu Sahashi]], over delayed and unpaid [[wage]]s, but Sahashi was ultimately not charged. It took roughly eight months for the company to reach the point where it filed for bankruptcy protection on 26 October 2007 whereupon the trading of its stock was suspended and was delisted on 27 November 2007. On 6 November 2007 court-appointed receivers announced that [[Nagoya]]-based [[G.Communication]] would sponsor Nova. Initial plans by G.com were to start with reopening up to 30 schools in various locations including Tokyo and Osaka by the end of November 2007. G.com later sold off its 490 Nova and 167 GEOS English schools on 1 October 2010 to Inayoshi Holdings, with 50 of the GEOS schools slated to join the Nova group under the name "Nova x Geos"Retooled English school chains set to launch Nova x Geos brand http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/business/T101014003658.htm Retrieved 16 October 2010 on 1 November 2010. As of 1 February 2012 Nova is owned by Jibun Mirai Associe Co. Ltd.{{cite web|title=Jibun Mirai website|url=http://www.jibunmirai.co.jp/|accessdate=6 June 2012}} On 2 September 2013 Jibun Mirai established a wholly owned subsidiary called Nova and fully reinstated the name Nova.Japan Times [http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2013/09/04/business/nova-reinstated-as-name-of-english-language-school-chain/ Nova reinstated as name of English-language school chain 4 September 2013] As of January 2014 Nova operates 310 branches,{{cite web|title=スクール検索|url=http://www.nova.co.jp/schools/|accessdate=2 January 2014}} with 66,000 students.Japan Times [http://www.japantimes.co.jp/community/2013/11/03/general/six-years-following-bankruptcy-nova-boosts-the-brand/ Six years following bankruptcy, Nova boosts the brand 3 November 2013] ==History== [[File:NOVA branch.JPG|thumb|A Nova branch]] The Nova Group was founded in August 1981 and was led by CEO [[Nozomu Sahashi]]. {{cite web |url=http://www.ekimae-nova.com/ |title=Nova Corporate profile |accessdate=21 March 2007 |publisher=nova.ne.jp |date=2002–2003 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071104082542/http://www.nova.ne.jp/english/corporation/05gaiyou/gaiyou.html |archivedate=4 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Nova's corporate headquarters were in Osaka. The company was the largest employer of foreign nationals in Japan, {{cite web |url= http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl20050531zg.html |title= New Nova hours pose health risk |accessdate=4 June 2007 |publisher= The Japan Times |date= 31 May 2005 }} employing 7,000 foreign workers, 5,000 of whom were employed as language instructors. {{cite web |url= http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl20050412zg.html |title= English schools face huge insurance probe |accessdate=20 March 2007 |publisher= The Japan Times |date=12 April 2005 }} Each year, Nova hired between 2,500 and 2,600 foreign teachers to replace those who had left. {{cite web |url= http://www.nova.ne.jp/ir/news/news070201.html |title= Notice from Nova regarding news reports |accessdate=29 March 2007 |publisher= Nova Web Site |date= 31 January 2007 }} Although instructors were not required to have actual educational training, the company provided a salary bonus for teachers with an accredited [[TEFL]] certificate, any master's degree, or a degree in education. Teachers were admitted directly after university graduation with any degree that allowed them to obtain a work visa. Instructors from participating countries {{cite web |url= http://www.mofa.go.jp/j_info/visit/w_holiday/index.html |title= Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan |accessdate=5 June 2007 |publisher= Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan}} who can obtain a [[Working Holiday Visa]] were admitted without a degree. They worked fewer hours and earned less pay than full-time instructors. Sahashi originally established the company with two high school graduates from Sweden and Canada whom he met via a friend who was studying abroad in Paris. They opened the first classroom in Shinsaibashi, Osaka. The name ''[[Nova]]'' (an astronomical term for a stellar explosion) was chosen by Sahashi as he felt it would appeal to prospective students. {{cite web |url=http://osaka.yomiuri.co.jp/eco_news/20070614ke03.htm |title=Nova – Restrictions Inevitable |accessdate=3 July 2007 |publisher=Yomiuri Shimbun |date=14 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Q48bIjXK?url=http://osaka.yomiuri.co.jp/eco_news/20070614ke03.htm |archivedate=3 July 2007 |df=dmy }} In November 1996, Nova's [[initial public offering]] was met with several demonstrations in front of [[Nomura Securities]] and the [[Tokyo Stock Exchange]]. A complaint filed by The [[National Union of General Workers|Nova Union]] stated that the company was violating Japanese exchange laws by falsely stating that there were no unions at Nova, nor pending litigation, and that labor relations between the company and its employees were amicable and untroubled.[http://www.novaunion.com/zet/UB8.html Media Critical of Nova in Wake of Public Stock Offering][http://www.novaunion.com/zet/M6.html "Union, management speak two tongues"] The Japan Times (31 January 1997)[http://www.novaunion.com/zet/M4.html "Nova is accused of lying in stock-listing prospectus"] The Japan Times, 19 December 1996 Since 1997, Nova steadily expanded the number of its schools as its business grew, going from 239 schools to 623 in 2004. By 2002, Nova had captured 50% of total market share by revenue (61.5 billion yen) and in 2003, Nova had gained a 66% market share by number of students, some 410,000 students in total. However 2005 saw Nova lose ground in total sales revenue. {{cite web |url=http://www.nova.ne.jp/ir/pdf/02market_share.pdf |title=Nova Corp. Website |accessdate=15 August 2007 |publisher=Nova |date= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5R3qwhhXL?url=http://www.nova.ne.jp/ir/pdf/02market_share.pdf |archivedate=13 August 2007 |df=dmy }} The company was in the red in the business year ending in March for the second consecutive year, {{cite web |url = http://cc.msnscache.com/cache.aspx?q%3D8321206067110%26lang%3Dja-JP%26mkt%3Dja-JP%26FORM%3DCVRE6 |archive-url = https://www.webcitation.org/5R2Dh0oT3?url=http://cc.msnscache.com/cache.aspx?q=8321206067110&lang=ja-JP&mkt=ja-JP&FORM=CVRE6 |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 12 August 2007 |title = Executives of scandal-tainted companies bow in remorse at shareholder meetings |accessdate = 12 August 2007 |publisher = Mainichi |date = 28 June 2007 |df = dmy-all }} posting net losses of 3 billion yen in fiscal 2005 and 2.4 billion yen in fiscal 2006 after a failed expansion attempt. The number of students fell to 418,000 by the end of March: down 12.1 percent from a year earlier. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706180093.html |title=Services: Nova Corp. eyes capital tie-up |accessdate=17 August 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun |date=18 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5R1kfNLUF?url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706180093.html |archivedate=12 August 2007 |df=dmy }} On 20 September 2007, NOVA announced it was considering a large-scale closure of up to 200 branches. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/life/update/0920/OSK200709200039.html |title=Nova considers closing 200 classrooms |accessdate=20 September 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun |date=20 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5RzMGrqvI?url=http://www.asahi.com/life/update/0920/OSK200709200039.html |archivedate=20 September 2007 |df=dmy }} ===Events after the collapse=== The announcement of court protection and the admission that operations at all Nova branches would be temporarily shut down shocked the estimated 420,000 Nova students as some of them had paid their tuition in advance and feared their money might not be refunded. The [[Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry]] asked the [[Japan Association for the Promotion of Foreign Language Education]], an industry body, to call on its member schools to accept Nova students. METI also requested consumer credit companies not to seek loan repayments from the 20% of Nova students who paid their tuition with loans because Nova has ceased operations and they could not take lessons. {{cite web |url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/420669 |title=Gov't reluctant to get involved in bailing out Nova |accessdate=29 October 2007 |publisher=Kyodo News |date=27 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Sx8l386b?url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/420669 |archivedate=29 October 2007 |df=dmy }} Nova President [[Nozomu Sahashi]], missing since before his dismissal, was officially replaced by three board members, including co-founder [[Anders Lundqvist]]. The Osaka Labor Bureau, a local branch of the [[Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (Japan)|Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare]], launched a consulting counter with five interpreters for foreign Nova instructors. {{cite web |url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/420582 |title=Nova granted court protection from creditors; president missing |accessdate=30 October 2007 |publisher=Kyodo News |date=26 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5SyBTy4Zy?url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/420582 |archivedate=30 October 2007 |df=dmy }} The immediate effect of collapse of Nova was the sudden unemployment of approximately 4,500 foreign teaching staff and 2,000 Japanese workers. The desperate situation of many of the foreign teachers raised concerns over an apparent lack of an adequate safety net for foreign workers in Japan. Some teachers could not even afford a plane ticket home. {{cite web |url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20071108/wl_asia_afp/japaneducationbankruptcycompanynova |title=English teachers feel abandoned after Japanese giant collapses |accessdate=9 November 2007 |publisher=Kyodo News |date=7 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5TDMgfEKy?url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20071108/wl_asia_afp/japaneducationbankruptcycompanynova |archivedate=9 November 2007 |df=dmy }} The Australian and British embassies in Japan set up information pages on their websites to assist their nationals and Qantas airline offered reduced airfares for Australian Nova employees wishing to return to Australia. {{cite web |url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/420690 |title=Australian, British embassies assisting Nova instructors; Qantas offers cheaper fares home |accessdate=27 October 2007 |publisher=Kyodo News |date=28 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5SuvlAHTA?url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/420690 |archivedate=28 October 2007 |df=dmy }} The collapse led to huge increases in union membership, particularly in [[National Union of General Workers|NUGW Tokyo Nambu]] (future Tozen Union) and in Osaka's [[General Union]]. The unions had a chance to appeal their case to the public thanks to extensive coverage on TV, radio and newspaper. The unexpected influx of ex-Nova teachers on the job market led to immense numbers of applicants vying for a much smaller number of employment opportunities. Language education companies, even some outside Japan, attempted to tap into this labor force. {{cite web |url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/421212 |title=EF invites Nova instructors to teach in China for Olympics |accessdate=8 November 2007 |publisher=Kyodo News |date=8 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5TLpA67V0?url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/421212 |archivedate=14 November 2007 |df=dmy }} The publicity, generated by the collapse in Japan and in other countries, also threatened to damage the reputation of Japan's foreign language industry although the Japanese government attempted to minimize the damage by pledging non-specific support despite remaining essentially uninvolved in the chaotic collapse. The government did set up a special consultation booth briefly at the [[Hello Work]] public employment office in Shinjuku in Tokyo for Nova instructors seeking advice but maintained its distance as its position was that the bankruptcy of Japan's biggest foreign language school chain was a private sector matter. Although Nova was unable to successfully attract a corporate partner to stave off the bankruptcy, twelve companies quickly applied for sponsorship to rebuild Nova Corp, some of which made specific proposals to turn around the company. {{cite web |url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/421036 |title=12 companies apply for sponsorship to rebuild Nova |accessdate=5 November 2007 |publisher=Kyodo News |date=5 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5T8MnIRAj?url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/421036 |archivedate=5 November 2007 |df=dmy }} ===Restructuring=== On 7 November 2007, [[G.Communication]], a Nagoya-based operator of cram schools, language schools and restaurant chains announced it had been unofficially selected to take over part of the operations of failed Nova Corp before any official decision by the board of trustees had been released. G.Education Co, a subsidiary of G.communication, would take over part of Nova's operations in addition to the chain of [[EC Inc]] English conversation schools of Hokkaido it runs. Nova Corp assets not absorbed by G.communication would be liquidated by court appointed administrators. The administrators claimed they had to select a sponsor quickly even before the court approved Nova's reconstruction program as value of Nova corporate assets were eroding each day as employees and students left. {{cite web |url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/421159 |title=Nagoya-based G.communication to take over part of Nova operations |accessdate=6 November 2007 |publisher=Kyodo News |date=7 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5TOGS8cwK?url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/421159 |archivedate=16 November 2007 |df=dmy }} Initial plans by G.communication were to start with reopening the Nova Kurokawa school in Nagoya's Kita Ward with the intention to reopen up to 30 schools in various locations including Tokyo & Osaka by the end of November 2007. G.communication held several briefing sessions for Nova employees and foreign teachers about their reemployment. Although many of the foreign teachers were not subsequently re-employed, G.communication has opened 465 schools as of January 2010. {{cite web |url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/421397 |title=G.communication to reopen 1st Nova school in Nagoya |accessdate=12 November 2007 |publisher=Kyodo News |date=11 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5THfwcWpX?url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/421397 |archivedate=12 November 2007 |df=dmy }} G.communication Co. sold off the Nova and Geos chains of English schools on 1 October 2010. An investment company led by Masaki Inayoshi, who formerly served as chairman of G.communication, purchased the subsidiary of the Nagoya-based firm that ran both GEOS and Nova.Geos, Nova English schools change ownership once again http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/business/T101005004522.htm Retrieved 16 October 2010 At the time of sale, Nova had 490 locations and Geos 167. Nova changed ownership again in 2012, being purchased by Jibun Mirai Associe Co. Ltd. However G.communication continues to operate some Nova schools through its subsidiaries G.networks and G.taste, under license from Jibun Mirai Associe. ==Branches as of 2012== As of May 2012 there are 212 Nova branches operating. 211 are located across Japan: nineteen in Hokkaido, nineteen in Kyushu, ten in Chugoku, six in Shikoku, thirty-six in Kansai, seventy-six in Kanto, and forty-five in Chubu; Nova has one branch located in Hawaii.{{cite web|title=ハワイ校|url=http://www.nova.co.jp/schools/1583.shtml|accessdate=23 May 2012}} ==Marketing and services== [[File:Nova-newinside-2008.jpg|thumb|The interior of a new Nova school showing the new design motifs]] Prior to its 2007 bankruptcy, the language school chain aggressively operated extensive advertising campaigns in print and on television and had a very high profile and strong [[brand recognition]]. {{cite web |url= http://archive.salon.com/people/feature/2000/06/29/japancelebs/ |title= How U.S. stars sell Japan to the Japanese |accessdate=30 June 2007 |publisher= Salon.com |date= 29 June 2000}} {{cite book | last = Philip Seargeant | first = Seargeant | title = "More English than England itself": the simulation of authenticity in foreign language practice in Japan | publisher = International Journal of Applied Linguistics | year = 2005 | pages = 326–345 | doi = 10.1111/j.1473-4192.2005.00094.x }} Until a short time before its collapse, Nova used an animated pink rabbit (the "Nova Usagi") as the popular face of the company, which appeared often as the focus of Nova's TV commercials and other advertisements. {{cite web |url= http://mdn.mainichi-msn.co.jp/waiwai/archive/news/2003/03/20030303p2g00m0dm999000c.html |title= Nova's abused bunny ad leaves activists hopping mad |accessdate=15 August 2007 |publisher= Mainichi |date= 3 March 2003}} The rabbit appealed strongly to children and became extremely popular. The introduction of "Nova Usagi" merchandise saw sales of over 260 million yen in the first two weeks of availability. {{cite web |url=http://www.jmintelligence.co.jp/trends/trends_2004_winter.html |title=Japan Market Research |accessdate=15 August 2007 |publisher=Japan Market Intelligence |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070430090958/http://www.jmintelligence.co.jp/trends/trends_2004_winter.html |archivedate=30 April 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Nova partially discontinued using the rabbit in January 2003 after [[JSPCA]] animal rights activists lodged a protest over a commercial that featured the rabbit getting its ears ripped off, citing concerns of its impact on children's awareness of death. Many Nova branches were (and still are) located near [[train station]]s, and the company used the term ''ekimae ryūgaku'' ("study abroad near the train station": 駅前留学) in its promotional materials. The catch phrase helped Nova to become the nation's biggest chain of English language schools.{{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706160079.html |title=Exploiting the zeal of Japanese to learn English |accessdate=1 July 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun |date=16 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Q0QUoDwC?url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706160079.html |archivedate=1 July 2007 |df=dmy }} It similarly promoted its interactive multimedia network as ''ochanoma ryūgaku'' ("study abroad from the living room": お茶の間留学).{{cite web |url=http://www.nova.ne.jp/english/corporation/02jigyo/jigyou_ekicha.html |title=Nova Corp. Website |accessdate=15 August 2007 |publisher=Nova |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070610043100/http://www.nova.ne.jp/english/corporation/02jigyo/jigyou_ekicha.html |archivedate=10 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Nova's success was also attributed to its promises of a foreign teacher, smaller class sizes than its rivals, and an appointment system that allowed students to schedule and attend class at their convenience.{{cite web |url=http://www.novaunion.com/zet/M7.html |title=Nova students say they are learning how to watch their money disappear |accessdate=12 August 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun, reprinted with permission Nova Union website |date=1 February 1997 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5R3BDpJGf?url=http://www.novaunion.com/zet/M7.html |archivedate=13 August 2007 |df=dmy }} However, in 1997, 18 students filed a [[grievance]] with the [[Tokyo Metropolitan Government]] claiming they were unable to make lesson appointments when they wanted, despite the school's advertisements that its students could reserve classes "at any time". The students said they had purchased hundreds of tickets when joining the school, but found it impossible to use them all by the expiry date due to inflexible scheduling procedures. Nova agreed to a proposal by the Damage Relief Committee to repay a total of 3.8 million yen and said the dispute had been the result of a misunderstanding.[http://www.novaunion.com/zet/M9.html "Nova to refund 3.8 million yen for students' unused lessons"] The Japan Times 13 June 1997. Reprinted with permission by Nova Union. Retrieved on 11 February 2007 ===Services=== The company offered English courses for adults, children, business English and test preparation ([[TOEFL]], [[TOEIC]]) as well as [[Chinese (language)|Chinese]], [[French (language)|French]], [[Spanish (language)|Spanish]], [[Italian (language)|Italian]], and [[German (language)|German]] instruction. Through subsidiaries, the company also offered [[telecommunications]] and [[travel agency]] services and in-house English instruction, [[translation]] and [[Language interpretation|interpretation]] services for Japanese corporations.{{cite web |url= http://www.glova.co.jp/ |title= Glova Website |accessdate=7 February 2007 |publisher= Glova |date= 6 June 2007 }} {{cite book | last = Graham | first = Jeffery |author2=Hideaki Miyajima |author3=Javed Maswood | title = Japan – Change and Continuity | publisher = Routledge | year = 2002 | isbn = 0-7007-1644-0 | page = 119 }} While Nova's main product was English language services, the company shifted some of its focus toward China, as 100,000 of its students studied Chinese.{{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706180116.html |title=Sizing up China: Language students put their money where their mouths are |accessdate=21 August 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun |date=16 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5R1kcvjPI?url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706180116.html |archivedate=12 August 2007 |df=dmy }} ==Instructor employment system== * '''Full-time instructor'''Jibun Mirai Associe webpage [http://www.jibunmirai.co.jp/foreigner/working.html Working Conditions] Retrieved on 11 June 2012 ** Five day work week of eight 44-minute lessons per day. Duties may include cleaning or distributing tissues during free lessons ** 253,000 yen monthly salary which may vary depending on class capacity. Teachers are paid more for full or one on one classes, less for one or two student classes ** Transport allowance included in salary ** 10 paid holidays per year in the first 12-month contract. Different schools vary in whether they give public holidays or not. == Employment and labor relations == ===Drug testing=== In 1994, after two instructors were arrested on drug charges in August and September, Nova asked all 3,100 instructors to sign an agreement to have a mandatory drug test, the results of which would be reported to the police. The drug test only applied to foreign staff.{{cite web |url=http://www.novaunion.com/zet/M2.html |title=Nova teachers seeking legal help |accessdate=11 February 2007 |publisher=The Japan Times, Reprinted with permission by Nova Union |date=1 October 1994 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070727185208/http://www.novaunion.com/zet/M2.html |archivedate=27 July 2007 |df=dmy }} [http://www.novaunion.com/zet/M3.html "Nova teachers pan drug test: staffers urge school to end 'illegal labor practices'"] The Japan Times 1994 Reprinted with permission by Nova Union. Retrieved on 11 February 2007 The Osaka Bar Association wrote an opinion that the policy was a violation of the teachers' right to privacy.[http://www.generalunion.org/nova/drugruling.htm Letter of Recommendation] Osaka Bar Association. Retrieved on 20 March 2007 Nova claimed consent forms had been received from more than 90 percent of employees. According to the union, no instructors were ever required to take a drug test.[http://www.novaunion.com/zet/accomplishments.html "Our Accomplishments"] Nova Union of Teachers. Retrieved on 11 February 2007 ===Shakai hoken=== In March 2005, after NUGW Tokyo Nambu and the [[National Union of General Workers|General Union]] filed a complaint, Nova and other English schools in Japan were investigated by the [[Social Insurance Agency]] for not enrolling employees in {{nihongo |Social Insurance|[[:ja:社会保険|社会保険]],| Shakai Hoken }}. The law stipulates that companies with full-time workers who have been in Japan for more than two months must enroll them in the system. Payment is split between employer and employee, each paying about half the monthly premium amount.{{cite web |url= http://search.japantimes.co.jp/member/member.html?appURL=fl20050412zg.html |title= English schools face huge insurance probe |accessdate=20 March 2007 |publisher= The Japan Times |date= 12 April 2005 }} In June 2005, Nova amended its working times for instructors and standardized lesson length to 40 minutes, with two minutes either side for lesson planning and student evaluation, resulting in a total lesson time of 44 minutes. Six to eleven minutes of unpaid time was left between classes. As a result of changes to working hours, regular non-titled teachers whose work weeks were reduced to slightly under 30 hours became ineligible for ''shakai hoken'', giving an estimated savings to the company of over one billion yen in annual premium payments. Such employees can register for [[National Health Insurance (Japan)|National Health Insurance]] (a different system to Shakai Hoken), although this system does not offer coverage for time taken off work due to illness. Nova also offered its own private insurance program. === Anti-fraternization policy === After six employees were fired for violating a clause in their contracts that forbade interaction between students and instructors outside the classroom, a complaint was filed with the [[Attorney at law (Japan)|Osaka Bar Association]] by two employees who were members of the General Union, one of whom had been dismissed as a result of the policy. The two instructors claimed the policy violated their human rights and argued it was racial discrimination since it only applied to foreigners. The clause in Nova's labor contract stated that foreign teachers "should not have a relationship with customers outside the workplace."[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/member/member.html?nn20030301b8.htm Nova's ban on dating violates rights: teachers] The Japan Times (1 March 2003) retrieved 1 July 2007 The Osaka Bar Association subsequently issued a non-binding recommendation that the company drop the clause, saying that it restricted instructors' freedom of association and discriminated between foreign and Japanese staff.[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20040226b4.html Nova, let teachers date students: bar] The Japan Times (26 February 2004). Retrieved on 1 July 2007 The company said the clause was there to "protect both the teachers and the students from trouble, as they do not know each other's cultures and customs."[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl20040601zg.html No sex please, you're teachers: Nova teachers unhappy with rules, reports] The Japan Times (1 June 2004). Retrieved on 22 March 2007 On 11 December 2005, an Australian who had been teaching in an Osaka Nova branch reached an out-of-court settlement of ¥400,000[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/member/nn20051211a2.html Nova to pay teacher over demotion] The Japan Times(11 December 2005). Retrieved on 1 July 2007 and a letter of commendation after claiming that the policy had interfered with his life. The then 30-year-old teacher had been demoted and transferred to another school branch in 2004 when Nova found out he had a relationship with a 21-year-old student. {{cite web |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/hard-lessons-from-teaching-english-in-japan/2006/03/14/1142098460885.html?page=fullpage |title= Hard lessons in broken English |accessdate=21 August 2007 |publisher= Sydney Morning Herald |date= 15 March 2006}} === Contested dismissals === In November 2004, union supporters gathered outside Nova's Shinjuku Honko school, protesting dismissals of five teachers, three of whom had been working at Nova for more than 10 years. All were members of the Nova union (a branch of the [[National Union of General Workers|NUGW]]). The union alleged they were dismissed due to their union activities. {{cite web |url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl20041123zg.html |title= Class Action |accessdate=21 August 2007 |publisher= Japan Times |date= 23 November 2004}} In March 2006, Kara Harris reached a financial settlement with Nova for approximately 7 million yen after she had been dismissed following her request to be made a permanent employee during negotiations with Nova over her sixth consecutive contract. {{cite web |url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl20060328zg.html |title= Times get tough for teachers |accessdate=21 August 2007 |publisher= Japan Times |date= 28 March 2006}} Nova had originally offered her a 12-month extension and, after disputes with her manager over several issues, she sued Nova for wrongful dismissal. Successive courts found that Harris was unfairly treated by Nova. ===Unions=== Throughout Japan staff at Nova are represented by various unions. In Kyushu some staff belong to the Fukuoka General union,Fukuoka General Union website [http://fukuoka.generalunion.org/news/nova_september2007.html Nova issues] Retrieved on 1 June 2012 in Kansai some instructors belong to the [[General Union]].General Union website [http://www.generalunion.org/nova/] Retrieved on 1 June 2012 Both of these unions belong to the [[National Union of General Workers]], which is itself a member of the confederation [[Zenrokyo]] (National Trade Union Council).General Union website [http://www.generalunion.org/affiliation General Union Affiliation] Retrieved on 1 June 2012 ==Government intervention== ===Concerns about refund policy=== On 14 February 2007, the Ministry of Trade, Economy and Industry and the Tokyo Metropolitan Government conducted on-the-spot inspections at Nova Headquarters in Osaka and several other branches. {{cite web |url=http://www.zakzak.co.jp/top/2007_02/t2007021624.html |title=Inspection over frequent cancellation problems at Nova |accessdate=13 August 2007 |publisher=ZakZak |date=16 February 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5QpOc1QS0?url=http://www.zakzak.co.jp/top/2007_02/t2007021624.html |archivedate=3 August 2007 |df=dmy }} Officials said that several Nova schools failed to give full refunds to students who canceled their remaining lessons after paying in advance. Other clients said that Nova refused to accept unconditional cancellation of lessons, claiming the eight-day "cooling-off" period had expired, and had also deceived students by giving false information about their cancellation procedures.[https://www.webcitation.org/5Q0Ll32vD?url=http://cc.msnscache.com/cache.aspx?q=8247506639759&lang=ja-JP&mkt=ja-JP&FORM=CVRE3 "Nova raided after complaints over missing tuition fees"] Mainichi Daily News 16 February 2007. Retrieved on 1 June 2007 The ''Asahi Shimbun'' cites an example of a contract for 100 lessons, which would cost 230,000 yen in advance, for a per-lesson fee of 2,300 yen. A contract for 600 lessons would require an advance payment of 720,000 yen, or 1,200 yen per class. Such students say the contract for 1,200 yen per lesson should have applied in these cases, which would result in a refund of 600,000 yen. ===Supreme Court appeal rejected=== On 4 April 2007, Nova's appeal on two lower court rulings was rejected by the [[Supreme Court of Japan|Supreme Court]] which described Nova's refund policy as invalid and in violation of specified commercial transaction law.[http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200704040097.html "Top court: Nova's refund tactic illegal"] The Asahi Shimbun 4 April 2007. Nakayama, who was elected from an Osaka constituency (of which Sahashi was a member of the lawmaker's support organization) recalled saying at the time that it was "not right by social norms that Nova's refund rule is unacceptable" and explained "it is a politician's job to help out when a supporter is in trouble." Nakayama stated it was not his intention to exert pressure and Mayor Seki said he did not think the judgment of city officials was swayed by the lawmaker's visit. Industry minister [[Akira Amari]] also admitted on 22 June 2007 that he met with Yasuhide Nakayama earlier that year in February shortly after his ministry began investigating the school. Nakayama sought a meeting with Amari to express concern that the ministry might discipline the school over its fee discount system. Amari stated that Nakayama did not try to sway him from punitive action. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706230091.html |title=Tokyo: Amari admits visit over Nova inquiry |accessdate=21 August 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun |date=23 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/20070614TDY01002.htm |title=Nova barred from making long contracts |accessdate=1 July 2007 |publisher=Yomiuri Shimbun |date=14 June 2007 |deadurl=yes Nova was requested to submit an additional report. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/special/070614/TKY200706270397.html |title=Nova Improvement plan lacks details |accessdate=16 August 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun |date=13 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5R9RdTp5k?url=http://www.asahi.com/special/070614/TKY200706270397.html |archivedate=17 August 2007 |df=dmy }} ===Events following restrictions=== In an interview in ''[[The Daily Yomiuri]]'' on 16 June 2007, Sahashi said he was considering offers of capital and business alliances from several companies in various industries, including retail firms, to deal with an expected drop in sales and to restore trust in the company and possibly selling off properties and real estate in Osaka estimated to be worth several billion yen.[https://www.webcitation.org/5Q0Q60A0Y?url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/business/20070616TDY01003.htm Nova boss weighs assistance options] The Daily Yomiuri (16 June 2007). (travel agency)|H.I.S. travel agency]], to discuss a financial assistance as well as a business tie-up[http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200707030119.html Travel agency H.I.S. eyes alliance with struggling Nova] The Asahi Shimbun (3 July 2007). On 14 August 2007 Nova announced and subsequently sold 170,000 new shares on 30 August. {{cite web |url= https://www.release.tdnet.info/inbs/380e0610_20070814.pdf |format=PDF|title= Stock Issue Announcement |accessdate=21 August 2007 |publisher= JASDAQ |date= 14 August 2007}} ==2007 financial crisis== Indications of an impending financial crisis stemmed from a rapid increase in refund claims that total nearly 5,000,000,000 yen nationwide. A 21 August 2007, article in the ''[[Toyo Keizai]]'', Nova was described as repeatedly delaying payment to business partners and banks, falling into arrears for printing costs at the end of July, asking an ad agency to defer a payment. {{cite web |url = http://www.toyokeizai.net/online/tk/headline/detail.php?kiji_no%3D209%26page%3D |archive-url = https://www.webcitation.org/5RFuxu6RU?url=http://www.toyokeizai.net/online/tk/headline/detail.php?kiji_no=209&page= |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 21 August 2007 |title = The end of the road for Nova's business practices as cash flow crunch intensifies |accessdate = 21 August 2007 |publisher = Toyo Keizai (Toyo Economics) |date = 21 August 2007 |df = dmy-all }} Nova's 2007 first quarter financials showed a loss of 4,300,000,000 yen, a 19% decrease in sales compared to the previous year period, and an overall 19% decrease in recurring profit. Nova cited the decrease in the number of students and deterioration of its image as an explanation. {{cite web |url = http://company.nikkei.co.jp/news/news.cfm?Nik_Code%3D0030030%26Page%3D1%26Back_sid%3DIR_CT%26KIJIID%3D20070827NSS0163%26DATE_FORSEARCH%3D2007/08/27 |archive-url = https://www.webcitation.org/5RTN7kZzd?url=http://company.nikkei.co.jp/news/news.cfm?Nik_Code=0030030&Page=1&Back_sid=IR_CT&KIJIID=20070827NSS0163&DATE_FORSEARCH=2007%2F08%2F27 |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 30 August 2007 |title = Nova sees decrease in students and 4,300,000,000 yen loss in Q1. |accessdate = 30 August 2007 |publisher = Nikkei Market News |date = 27 August 2007 |df = dmy-all }} {{cite web |url = http://company.nikkei.co.jp/news/news.cfm?Nik_Code%3D0030030%26Page%3D1%26Back_sid%3DIR_CT%26KIJIID%3D20070825NKM0229%26DATE_FORSEARCH%3D2007/08/25 |archive-url = https://www.webcitation.org/5RTN9ht22?url=http://company.nikkei.co.jp/news/news.cfm?Nik_Code=0030030&Page=1&Back_sid=IR_CT&KIJIID=20070825NKM0229&DATE_FORSEARCH=2007%2F08%2F25 |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 30 August 2007 |title = Nova down 4,300,000,000 yen loss in Q1, sees decrease in student enrollment. |accessdate = 30 August 2007 |publisher = Nikkei Market News |date = 25 August 2007 |df = dmy-all }} The ''[[Asahi Shimbun]]'' reported on 11 September 2007, that Nova had made a request to an asset management consulting company, requiring them to return an outstanding amount of 8 million shares that were loaned to them on 30 July 2007. Nova Corporation said that they were not involved in planning the transaction. {{cite web |url=http://www.sponichi.co.jp/society/flash/KFullFlash20070925059.html |title=Nova financing via 9 million share mortgage? |accessdate=25 September 2007 |publisher=Sponichi Annex News |date=25 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5S7MZYjid?url=http://www.sponichi.co.jp/society/flash/KFullFlash20070925059.html |archivedate=25 September 2007 |df=dmy }} A fax sent to branches after 9 pm on Friday 12 October informed all instructors that salaries would not be met on 15 October as scheduled. {{cite web |url= http://www.japanprobe.com/?p=2926 |title= No Pay For Nova Teachers on October 15th |accessdate=16 October 2007 |publisher= Japan Probe |date= 14 October 2007}} The fax promised a solution for 19 October, the day Nova was required to submit its new business plan to JASDAQ after its previous plan was rejected by the Securities Exchange on 5 October for being insufficient.{{cite web|url=http://mdn.mainichi.jp/national/news/20071006p2a00m0na034000c.html |title=Jasdaq rejects NOVA report on improvement measures |accessdate=16 October 2007 |publisher=Mainichi Daily News |date=24 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010123111/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/national/news/20071006p2a00m0na034000c.html |archivedate=10 October 2007 }} When salaries were not disbursed on 15 October, union representatives from both Tokyo based NAMBU Foreign Workers Caucus and the Osaka-based General Union approached the Labor Standards Inspection Office to file a report and request an inquest in unpaid wages. The Unions estimated that about 4,000 foreign teachers to salary went unpaid of which about 2,000 employees were still awaiting wages from the previous month that had been delayed since 27 September. The Unions also filed complaints reporting that Nova had withheld member's rent payment and the landlords had tried ask teachers to leave repeatedly. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/life/update/1016/TKY200710160415.html |title=NOVA unions consider effect of bankruptcy |accessdate=16 October 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shinbun |date=17 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Sfp027i6?url=http://www.asahi.com/life/update/1016/TKY200710160415.html |archivedate=18 October 2007 |df=dmy }} By 20 October there had been both union organized and wildcat strikes over the unpaid wages. The collapse caught some former teachers in such dire financial straits that they had to rely on their former students to feed them. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200711080113.html |title=Cover Story: Nova fallout |accessdate=8 November 2007 |publisher=Mainichi Daily News |date=8 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5TOnKUHwI?url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200711080113.html |archivedate=16 November 2007 |df=dmy }} ===Sahashi's removal=== On 26 October 2007, Nova's stock was delisted and all branches closed, following an emergency board meeting that removed Sahashi from his position as head of the company.{{cite web |url= http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20071026z1.html |title= NOVA files for Bankruptcy Protection |accessdate=27 October 2007 |publisher= The Japan Times |date= 26 October 2007}} In June 2008, after a volunteer questioning with Osaka Prefectural Police, a warrant was served and Sahashi was arrested on charges of [[embezzlement]]. Sahashi denied charges of wrongdoing and insisted that the 320 million yen reserve fund personally created through a firm affiliated with Nova effectively under Sahashi's control had been set up to refund tuition fees to students who had canceled their lessons.{{cite news | title = Former Nova chief arrested – Sahashi grilled over misuse of ¥320 million in worker benefits | publisher = The Japan Times| date = 25 June 2008| url = http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20080625a1.html | accessdate =30 July 2008}} === Nonpayment of employee housing rent === Foreign staff risked losing company-sponsored housing after Nova stopped paying their rent, which they did well before the official announcements of impending bankruptcy. Paul Dorey, an official of the General Union, said: "Some teachers have already received eviction notices. It’s a total mess."{{cite news | last= Soble | first= Jonathan | url= http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/92cd2da8-85b1-11dc-8170-0000779fd2ac.html | title= Nova hits Japan’s English lessons | publisher= [[Financial Times]] | date= 29 October 2007 | accessdate=29 October 2007 }} ==Lawsuits== The parents of a Nova employee who committed [[suicide]] in 2004 filed a suit against the company on 31 August 2007. Their son, age 28 at the time, was employed by Nova to design and supervise the construction of new classrooms. During that period Nova was engaged in a rapid expansion meant to increase the number of Nova branches by 300 in an attempt to reach a total of 1,000. The parents' suit alleges that their son was required by Nova to work up to 80 hours of overtime in one month, and even through the night on seven occasions, despite his inexperience. At one point he had requested to be relieved but was persuaded to stay, which eventually led to overwhelming stress shortly before his suicide. {{cite web |url = http://headlines.yahoo.co.jp/hl?a=20070901-00000126-mailo-l13 |title = Parents seek recognition for their son's suicide |accessdate = 1 September 2007 |publisher = Mainichi Daily News |date = 1 September 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5Razi0LgY?url=http://headlines.yahoo.co.jp/hl?a=20070901-00000126-mailo-l13 |archivedate = 4 September 2007 |df = dmy-all }} On 3 September 2007, an Osaka woman filed suit against Nova over a refund related issue. her unused points (worth approximately 400,000 yen) from the first contract would carry over after signing a new contract, she was not told that they could not be refunded if she chose to cancel. |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5bfaUCJAq?url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20081018b1.html |archivedate=18 October 2008 |df=dmy }} The suit further claims that Sahashi and his directors were negligent in their duties to fulfill obligations to customers. It also accuses five directors and two accounting firms of participating in the bankruptcy of Nova by allowing it to continue to use illicit accounting practices. Those accused allegedly inflated profit reports by recording 45% of the paid-in-advance tuition fees as part of its sales. The suit seeks a total of 16 million yen in compensation. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/kansai/news/OSK200810170008.html |title=24 former Nova students seek 16 million yen in compensation in class action suit |accessdate=18 October 2008 |publisher=[[Asahi Shimbun]] |date=17 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5bfaeJZkh?url=http://www.asahi.com/kansai/news/OSK200810170008.html |archivedate=18 October 2008 |df=dmy }} {{cite web |url = http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/national/news/20081017p2a00m0na010000c.html?inb=rs |title = Former students sue ex-NOVA managers for unreturned tuition fees |accessdate = 18 October 2008 |publisher = [[Mainichi Daily News]] |date = 17 October 2008 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081022033046/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/national/news/20081017p2a00m0na010000c.html?inb=rs |archivedate = 22 October 2008 |df = dmy }} == Lindsay Ann Hawker murder == {{main|Murder of Lindsay Hawker}} On 24 March 2007, [[Lindsay Hawker|Lindsay Ann Hawker]], a 22-year-old Nova teacher from Brandon near [[Coventry]], was murdered by 28-year-old Tatsuya Ichihashi. Her body was found three-days later in a sand-filled bathtub on the balcony of Ichihashi's apartment in [[Ichikawa, Chiba|Ichikawa]], [[Chiba Prefecture|Chiba]]. Police went to Ichihashi's apartment after Lindsay's flatmates had indicated she had gone there to teach an English lesson, but he managed to escape. He was captured in [[Osaka]] on 10 November 2009.[http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/national/news/20091110p2a00m0na027000c.html Mainichi.jp] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091112104707/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/national/news/20091110p2a00m0na027000c.html |date=12 November 2009 }} He later confessed to the murder and was sentenced to life imprisonment.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article5139609.ece|archive-url=https://archive.is/20081120070202/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article5139609.ece|dead-url=yes|archive-date=20 November 2008|title=Bill Hawker: Where is my daughter's killer?|publisher=''[[The Times]]''|date=16 November 2008|accessdate=18 November 2008 | location=London}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|https://www.nova.co.jp}} {{Ja icon}} * [http://www.transpacificradio.com/2007/10/01/nova-employees-their-voices-their-stories/ Nova Employees: Their Voices, Their Stories], Ken Worsley, posted Monday, 1 October 2007 at ''Trans-Pacific Radio'' {{Eikaiwa}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nova (Eikaiwa)}} [[Category:English conversation schools in Japan]] [[Category:Companies based in Osaka Prefecture]] [[Category:Companies established in 1981]] [[Category:Japanese business law]] [[Category:Human rights in Japan]] [[Category:Companies that have filed for bankruptcy in Japan]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Use South African English|date=November 2012}} Dr. '''Nthato Harrison Motlana''' (16 Feb 1925 – 1 December 2008) was a prominent [[South African]] businessman, physician and anti-apartheid activist.
==Life under Apartheid== He was tried alongside [[Nelson Mandela]] by the [[Apartheid]] regime during the [[Defiance Campaign]] of 1951–52, and played a prominent role during the [[Soweto uprising]] as one of the members of the [[Soweto Committee of Ten]]. <ref>[http://www.southafrica.info/mandela/nthato-motlana.htm ''Mandela mourns Nthato Motlana'' Southafrica.info]</ref> Motlana was a founding member of the [[Black Community Programme]], a group whose goal was to economically empower black South Africans, and he founded [[Phaphama Africa Commercial Enterprises]], [[Lesedi Clinic]] (the first black owned, private up-market hospital in the country), and [[Sizwe Medical Aid]] (the first black owned medical aid scheme in South Africa). <ref> Coetzee, C & Pienaar, H. (1999) "Nthato Harrison Motlana" from They Shaped our Century: The Most Influential South Africans of the Twentieth Century. Published by Human and Rousseau - p.364-368 http://www.sahistory.org.za/people/nthato-harrison-motlana </ref>
{{Rquote|right|'''''Motlana:''''' The [[Sharpeville Massacre]] chillingly portrayed the readiness of the state to use violence to counter and crush opposition, a willingness that has been seen time and time again since then.|From Discussions of the Inaugural Programme of the Africa Leadership Forum, Ota, Nigeria, 24 October to 1 November 1988 <ref> [https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:jqfwqAWnxZwJ:www.africaleadership.org/rc/apartheid%2520and%2520the%2520challenges%2520of%2520african%2520leaership.pdf+motlana+quotes&hl=en&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESjaydA0Cp62Cnk3vpoHbPBmodbbyUHzlzdS4lMIxCFbaayEGqsZmp1RJq1RuSkFQSiZtOFhE0sZ5vQ19XgRa9gurZvJGd3yJ02V1mq96KwNV7hRPgsDOKVmkOJteXYVDy4D73NE&sig=AHIEtbTw1EJ5P-O_LtnolIf_KZRwm4C-0A], African Leadership Forum, Ota, Nigeria, 24 October to 1 November 1988 </ref>}}
==Life after Apartheid== Following [[apartheid]], Motlana took a lead role in the formation of the [[New African Investments Limited]], or NAIL, which purchased many previously white run corporations at below market value. These included South Africa's largest newspaper ''[[The Sowetan]]''. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sparks|first=Colin|date=2009-05-01|title=South African media in transition|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/intellect/jams/2009/00000001/00000002/art00002|journal=Journal of African Media Studies|language=en|volume=1|issue=2|pages=195–220|doi=10.1386/jams.1.2.195_1|issn=2040-199X}}</ref> Due to his huge success in business Motalana earned the nickname "Father of Black Economic Empowerment." <ref>[http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736%2809%2960427-X/fulltext, The Lancet, Volume 373, Issue 9665, Page 716, 28 February 2009, Nthato Harrison Motlana]</ref>
Motlana served on the boards of [[Putco]], [[Rand Water|Rand Water Board]], [[Adcock Ingram Group]] and [[Sasol]], amongst other civic and academic institutions. <ref name=joburg>[http://www.joburg.org.za/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3255&Itemid=203 "Motlana: the passing of a great man" by, Ndaba Dlamini, Joburg.org]</ref>
==Death== He died on 1 December 2008 in a private hospital in [[Johannesburg]].<ref name=joburg />

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} '''Playbour''' (sometimes spelled '''playbor''') is a term used to describe a hybrid form of play and labour, specifically in the digital games industry. The term was coined by Julian Kücklich in 2005 in his article ''Precarious playbour: Modders and the digital games industry.'' Kücklich describes playbour as a type of free labour that fits neither traditional definitions of work nor the categories of play or leisure.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://journal.fibreculture.org/issue5/kucklich_print.html|title=Precarious Playbour: Modders and the Digital Games Industry|last=Kücklich|first=Julian|date=|website=journal.fibreculture.org|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref> Nevertheless, forms of playbour are often incorrectly perceived as being just an extension of play. Playbour is also sometimes categorized as a part of the [[gamification]] of society in general.
== History == While the term playbour itself is a relatively new invention, the phenomena it concerns – those of productive leisure and free labour in the digital games industry – have been around at least since the late 1990s. Kücklich states that since the early 1990s, the relationship between the players of digital games and the digital games industry has changed substantially. He attributes the alteration to the rise of computer [[game modification]], or "modding", as a widespread practice among players.<ref name=":0" />
=== Modding === Creating [[Mod (video gaming)|mods]] for digital games is the perfect example of playbour: a growing number of consumers of digital games are not satisfied with just playing the game, but prefer to enhance their playing experience by creating content for the game themselves. In modding we can see the very essence of playbour, or free labour: while the work of creating a modification can be seen as playful and enjoyable, it is still work. In this respect modding can be fairly similar to another form of collaborative digital production; [[Open-source software|open-source]] software development. The first game to gain a modder base of considerable size is widely agreed to be [[Doom (1993 video game)|Doom]] (1993).<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Sotamaa|first=Olli|date=3 September 2007|title=On modder labour, commodification of play, and mod competitions|url=http://journals.uic.edu/ojs/index.php/fm/article/view/2006|journal=First Monday|language=en-US|volume=12|issue=9}}</ref> The emergence of Doom mods is usually attributed to the fact that the game's code was deliberately designed to facilitate player-created content.<ref name=":1" /> The most famous modder creation is probably [[Counter-Strike]], originally a team-based mod for [[Half-Life (video game)|Half-Life]] (1998). It later also became the first commercially released mod.<ref name=":1" />
== Controversy around playbour and modding == Not only is modding a big part of [[Video game culture|gaming culture]], but it is also an increasingly important source of value for the digital games industry. Game companies usually retain the [[Intellectual property|intellectual property rights]] of the modifications. Since players need to have a copy of the original game to run the modifications, mods may add to the shelf-life of the product.<ref name=":1" /> In addition to that, mods may help with establishing [[brand]]s (e.g. Counter-Strike), thus saving companies a significant amount of money. Marketing costs often take up a large percentage of a game's budget, but successfully established brands require less marketing. Mods also increase customer loyalty and are an important source of innovation in the digital games industry.<ref name=":0" /> Another way that game companies can benefit from the modding culture is that they can recruit modders as employees who are already trained at no cost to the company.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ephemerajournal.org/contribution/playbour-farming-and-labour|title=Playbour, farming and labour|last=Goggin|first=Joyce|date=|website=www.ephemerajournal.org|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref>
While game companies may benefit economically from playbour, the players doing the work are not entirely uncompensated: they may obtain virtual in-game rewards or social capital such as followers on [[social media]]. The experience of play also has value in itself.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://thesocietypages.org/cyborgology/2012/10/15/gamification-playbor-exploitation-2/|title=Gamification, Playbor & Exploitation|last=Patella-Rey|first=PJ|date=16 October 2012|work=The Society Pages|access-date=2018-02-24|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref> Playbour is a voluntary activity and players don't usually view modding as labour. Nevertheless, it has been suggested that playboures are exploited by the games industry.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />

{{italic title}} '''''Property Report''''' is an [[English language]] [[magazine]] and [[website]] brand started in [[Thailand]] in April 2004 by the company Ensign Media from its offices in [[Bangkok]] and [[Phuket (city)|Phuket]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.property-report.com/site/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110226080233/http://www.property-report.com/site/ |archivedate=2011-02-26 |df= }}</ref>
==History== The magazine originally launched as ''Asia Property Report'', a bi-monthly 16-page staple bound publication with a newspaper style layout aimed at the real estate industry throughout [[Asia]].<ref>[http://www.property-report.com/site/about]</ref>
Within two issues, the title changed to ''Thailand Property Report'' and the readership focus shifted to investors as the company’s expatriate British founders, Terry Blackburn and Duncan Worthington, sought to capitalize on interest in the booming resort and luxury condominium real estate market in Thailand at the time. The local property market had remained stagnant since the [[Asian Financial Crisis of 1998|Asian financial crisis]] in 1998, but went through a period of unprecedented growth between 2004-2008. During this time, the magazine grew to be a 126-page, perfect bound publication, became the best selling real estate magazine in the country and expanded its distribution to [[Hong Kong]] and [[Singapore]], to take advantage of local interest in luxury Thai property. Due to local publication licensing laws the magazine was renamed ''Property Report Thailand'' in 2006.
In 2007, Ensign Media opened an office in Singapore in order to launch a sister magazine to ''Property Report Thailand'', ''Property Report Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia''. The publication’s primary areas of focus were Singapore, [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Bali]], [[Penang]] and [[Jakarta]]. Whilst the publisher reported strong subscriber numbers and newsstand sales, the magazine never attracted the same number of advertising pages as ''Property Report Thailand'', meaning its page count was always around 50% of its more established sibling publication. Plans to launch a Singapore Property Awards were announced but then shelved during the [[financial crisis of 2008]].
In June 2010, Ensign merged ''Property Report Thailand'' and ''Property Report Singapore, Malaysia Indonesia'' into a single publication, ''Property Report South East Asia''. The magazine was distributed in five countries: Singapore, [[Malaysia]], [[Indonesia]], Thailand and Hong Kong with a claimed circulation of 25,000 copies and was [[South East Asia]]’s only monthly [[real estate]] publication. Its [[editor in chief]] was UK national Andrew Batt, who was previously managing editor of ''[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]'' Thailand.<ref>[http://www.property-report.com/site/editorial-team-6705 Editorial Team] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715123038/http://www.property-report.com/site/editorial-team-6705 |date=2011-07-15 }}</ref>
==Property Report.com== In 2005, propertyreport.com was launched under the original magazine branding of Asia Property Report Online and widened the editorial reach of the magazine to cover residential real estate throughout Asia, as well as carrying property and business listings. The website’s most recent redesign was in July 2010, when it scrapped many of its superfluous sections and features to become more opinion, analysis and feature focused, and debuted a new property [[search engine]] and villa rental section.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://property-report.com site/editorial-team-6705|title=Property Report|accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref>
==Thailand Property Awards== In 2006, Ensign held the inaugural Thailand Property Awards, to recognize achievements in residential real estate. In order to avoid accusations of favoritism towards advertisers, the organizers used a panel of independent judges and monitoring of the process<ref>[http://www.cnngo.com/bangkok/life/desire-live-dream-keeps-thai-property-market-afloat-917007 CNN Go]</ref> by auditing firm BDO Advisory<ref>[http://www.bdo-thaitax.com/bdo/tpa2010-intro BDO Thai Tax]</ref> Whilst this occasionally produced controversial results, the awards continued to grow over the years and attracted over 500 attendees to the November 2010 gala dinner and considerable local and international [[News media|media]] coverage for winners<ref>[http://www.bangkokpost.com/business/economics/205272/golden-land-wins-award Bangkok Post]</ref>
In November 2010, Ensign Media announced plans for the South East Asia Property Awards to be held in Singapore in 2011.<ref>[http://www.ensign-media.com/south-east-asia-property-awards.html Ensign Media] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110710193619/http://www.ensign-media.com/south-east-asia-property-awards.html |date=2011-07-10 }}</ref>
==Distribution== ''Property Report'' is available for sale in major English language bookstores throughout Thailand, including [[Asia Books]], [[Kinokuniya]] and [[Bookazine]]. Complimentary copies can also be found in five star hotels, airport business lounges and at the [[Emirates (airline)|Emirates]] gate service at [[Suvarnabhumi Airport|Bangkok International Airport]]. Property Report is also available by subscription<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.property-report.com/site/about|title = Property Report|accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>

{{unreferenced|date=April 2012}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Raymond Rubicam | image = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1892|06|16}} | birth_place = [[Brooklyn, NY]] U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|1978|5|8|1892|06|16}} | death_place = [[Scottsdale, AZ]] U.S. | spouse = Regina McCloskey (m. 30-Nov-1916, div. 1939, three daughters); Bettina Hall (actress and singer, m. 16-Sep-1940) | children = Kathleen Bodine Rubicam
Jane Collins Rubicam
Anne Wilson Rubicam
Stephen Merril Rubicam
Joan Wister Rubicam | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | other_names = | known_for = Founder of [[Young & Rubicam]] | alma_mater = [[Colgate University]] (1947, ''honoris causa''); [[Boston University]] (1948, ''honoris causa''). | occupation = Advertising Executive }} '''Raymond Rubicam''' (June 16, 1892 – May 8, 1978) was an American advertising pioneer who co-established the [[Young & Rubicam]] (Y&R) [[advertising agency]] with [[John Orr Young]]. He retired from Y&R in 1944 at age 52. Raymond Rubicam's innovative leadership and creativity led many to recognize him as "advertising's statesman." Because his creative concepts and innovations have continued to play an important role in advertising as we know it today many people consider him the "father of modern advertising". ==Biography== As a young copywriter for N.W. Ayer and Son, Rubicam was responsible for some of advertising's most memorable pieces. Steinway's "The Instrument of the Immortals," Squibb's "The Priceless Ingredient," and Rolls-Royce's "No Rolls-Royce has ever worn out," were highly successful slogans which made him one of the industry's leading copywriters. While he enjoyed considerable success at N.W. Ayer, he felt that the agency failed to emphasize the importance of the creative artist in advertising. Rubicam, seeking to create an agency that valued artistic and creative talent over business, joined with James Orr Young to found Young & Rubicam in 1923. Rubicam's skills and his recruitment of the industry's most talented specialists propelled Young & Rubicam into the forefront of advertising. David Ogilvy credited Rubicam with assembling "the best team of copywriters and art directors in the history of advertising," whose advertisements "were read by more people than any other agency's." The agency represented many of America's leading companies, such as Gulf Oil, General Electric, Johnson and Johnson, Fortune, Life and others. While Raymond Rubicam's emphasis on creativity was innovative in itself, his philosophy and copywriting approach revolutionized the industry. He believed that an advertisement should "mirror the reader." Knowledge and understanding of the customer was a critical component of effective advertising. With the help of Dr. George Gallup, Rubicam pioneered new methods of consumer and media research. Young & Rubicam was the first agency to use scientific telephone sampling and to test audiences to measure the success of commercials and advertisements. The agency was also one of the first to produce their own programs, often integrating commercials into radio shows. The development of the "sequence-picture copy" was another Rubicam innovation. His was the first agency to use comic strips as a medium for advertising, creating "Mr. Coffee Nerves" for Postum and "Little Alby" for Grape-Nuts. Under his direction, Young & Rubicam made significant contributions to the war effort during World War II. The agency donated its time and resources to the War Advertising Council, the Treasury Department on War Loan Drives and to the Department of Agriculture for farm labor recruitment campaigns. Independently, Rubicam served as a special assistant to the War Manpower Commission, director of United China Relief, and later as a member of the Committee for Economic Development. The CED worked to support the United States during the war and significantly influenced policy following its conclusion. Rubicam also occupied several positions in the business world and contributed to the development of his community. He served as the director of the New York Life Insurance Company, Bates Manufacturing and Valley National Bank. ==External links== *[http://www.advertisinghalloffame.org/members/member_bio.php?memid=788 Advertising Hall Of Fame] – Raymond Rubicam, inducted in 1974 *[http://www.yr.com/ Young & Rubicam official website] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rubicam, Raymond}} [[Category:1892 births]] [[Category:1978 deaths]] [[Category:Advertising people]]

'''Resonate Group Limited''' is a British software, technology and services company. It was called DeltaRail Group Limited until renamed and re-branded in September 2016.
The company was formed from Rail business of [[AEA Technology|AEA Technology plc]] which was acquired as part of a [[secondary private equity]] portfolio sale to [[Vision Capital]] in 2006.<ref>{{cite press release| url=http://www.visioncapital.com/Media.htmx?year=100&itemid=Mjk0MTIwOTA0MzIwMQ==| title=Vision Capital Acquires Portfolio of Companies for £76.4 million| publisher=Vision Capital| year=2006 }}</ref> Previously, in 1998, AEA Technology plc formed the Rail business having acquired [[British Rail Research Division|British Rail Research]] from the [[British Rail|British Railways Board]], and a number of other [[engineering]] [[software]] organisations. On 21 January 2015, the four Executive Directors of the company acquired the business out of private equity ownership.
Resonate provides software, technology and services in three core areas; signalling control software, operational software and asset management products.
Resonate develops and maintains the [[Integrated Electronic Control Centre|Integrated Electronic Control Centre (IECC)]] widely used on Britain's rail networks.<ref>Control Systems - [http://www.resonate.tech Resonate Web Site]</ref>
The company has UK offices in [[Derby]] (head office) and [[London]].

In [[economics]], '''saving-investment balance''' or '''I-S balance''' is a balance of [[national savings]] and national investment, which is equal to [[current account]]. This relationship is obtained from the national income identity.
==Description== This is the national income identity:<ref>Christiano, 2003, [http://faculty.wcas.northwestern.edu/~lchrist/362/w2003/lect1.pdf Rough Notes on National Income Accounting and the Balance of Payments], Northwestern University, p.1.</ref> :<math>Y=C+I+G+(EX-IM)</math> where *Y: [[GDP]], *C: national [[consumption (economics)|consumption]], *I: national investment, *G: [[government spending]], *EX: [[export]], *IM: [[import]], *EX－IM: current account.
The national income identity can be rewritten as following:<ref name="nothwestern3">Christiano, 2003, [http://faculty.wcas.northwestern.edu/~lchrist/362/w2003/lect1.pdf Rough Notes on National Income Accounting and the Balance of Payments], Northwestern University, p.3.</ref> :<math>(Y-T-C)+(T-G)-I=EX-IM</math> where T is defined as [[tax]]. (Y-T-C) is savings of [[private sector]] and (T-G) is savings of government. Here, we define S as National savings (= savings of private sector + savings of government) and rewrite the identity as following: :<math>S-I=EX-IM</math> This identity implies that the difference of national savings and national investment is equal to current account.<ref name="nothwestern3" /><ref>IMF publishment, 2006, [http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/fandd/2006/12/basics.htm Do Current Account Deficits Matter?], accessed 3rd February 2015.</ref><ref>Tejvan Pettinger, 2012, [http://www.economicshelp.org/blog/6411/economics/current-account-savings-investment/ Current Account = Savings – Investment], EconomicsHelp.org, accessed 3rd February 2015.</ref>

'''Shah Abdul Hamid''' ({{lang-bn|শাহ আব্দুল হামিদ}}; 1900 – 1 May 1972) was a Bangladeshi political activist, [[Bangladesh Awami League|Awami League]] politician, legislator and banker.
==Early life== Hamid was born into a Muslim family in the village of Khalshi of Gobindagonj in [[Rangpur City|Rangpur]] district, [[East Bengal]], India, now Gaibandha, Bangladesh. His father was Hazi Abdul Gafur Shah and Mother Rahima Khatun.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Hamid,_Shah_Abdul| title= Hamid, Shah Abdul|author= Muhammad Moniruzzaman |date=2012 |website= banglapedia |publisher= Banglapedia |accessdate= 14 January 2015}}</ref> He was awarded a bachelor of arts from Carmicheal College of Rangpur in 1920.
Hamid participated in the Non Co-operation Movement initiated by Desh Bandhu Chitta Ranjan Das. In 1927, he obtained a law degree from Calcutta University and began practice at the Court of Gaibandha.
==Professional life== {{unreferenced section|date=May 2017}} After completion of his education, he returned to Gaibandha and started working as a sports organizer. He was the General Secretary of Gaibandha Town Club. He played the pioneer role in founding the Gaibandha College in 1947 of which he became the first Secretary of the Managing Committee. He was elected Chairman of the Rangpur School Board in 1949.
He was actively associated with "Jeorge Coronation Dramatic Club" (now Gibandha Nattya Sangstha) and performed on stage.
He was Director of the National Bank of Pakistan from 1951 to 1955.
==Political life== {{unreferenced section|date=May 2017}} Shah Abdul Hamid took part in the Law defying Movement in 1930. In 1936, he joined the Muslim League. In 1941, Hamid was elected Vice Chairman of Rangpur District Board, a post he was to hold for 12 years.
In 1945, he was elected Member of the Legislative Assembly of India. He joined Bangladesh Awami League in 1956 and was the President of Rangpur Awami League up to 1966.
In 1970, representing the Awami League, he was elected member for Gobindagonj-Polashbari on the National Assembly. At the very outset of the Liberation War, he went to India and played a vital role in organizing the Resistance movement.
Hamid was the first Speaker of the Gana Parishad (National Assembly), serving from 10 April to 1 May 1972.
The [[Shah Abdul Hamid Stadium]], Gaibandha, is named in his honour.

'''Thomas Anthony "T. A." Denny''' (2 April 1818 – 25 December 1909)<ref>{{cite book |title=The History of the Salvation Army : 1904-1914 |last=Wiggins |first=Arch R. |year=1964 |publisher=Nelson |isbn= |volume= v. 5 |page=261 }}</ref> was an [[Irish people|Irish]] bacon merchant, a self-described "pork philanthropist". Although not a member of the [[Salvation Army]], he supported it financially. His philanthropic activities also included support for education. In April 1868, he married Mary Jane Noel (1829-1887), daughter of [[Baptist Wriothesley Noel]]. In 1893, he married the evangelist [[Elizabeth Hope]], who was 24 years his junior.
==Salvation Army== Denny was one of a small group of wealthy benefactors who sustained the Salvation Army in its early years. He attended meetings called in 1877 by [[Samuel Morley (MP)|Samuel Morley]], another benefactor, to discuss differences with [[William Booth]], after which he continued to provide financial support despite continuing to disagree with Booth about doctrine and methods.<ref>{{cite book |title=The General: William Booth |last=Bennett |first=David Malcolm |year=2003 |publisher=[[Xulon Press]] |isbn=978-1-59467-206-4 |page=122–123 }}</ref> His support included, in 1881, paying the first year's rent on the organisation's headquarters at 101 [[Queen Victoria Street, London|Queen Victoria Street]] in [[London]]<ref>{{cite book |title=Salvation Army year book |year=1961 |publisher=[[Salvation Army|Salvationist Publishing and Supplies]] |page=21 }}</ref> and supporting the establishment of the Army in France.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Short Life of Catherine Booth the Mother of the Salvation Army |last=[[Frederick Tucker (Salvation Army)|St George De Lautour Booth-Tucker]]|first=Frederick |year=2005 |publisher=[[Kessinger Publishing]] |isbn=978-1-4179-6984-5 |page=342 }}</ref> In 1882 he contributed to the repayment of debts incurred for the building of barracks.<ref>{{cite news |title=The Salvation Army |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/3408744|work=[[The Brisbane Courier]] |date=10 July 1882 |accessdate=2009-04-22 }}</ref>
==Educational philanthropy== In 1890 Denny provided most of the funding for the buildings occupied by [[University of Greenwich|Woolwich Polytechnic]] and served as chairman of its board from 1891 to 1894.<ref>{{cite book |title=London Higher: The Establishment of Higher Education in London |last=Floud |first=Roderick |author2=Sean Glynn |year=1998 |publisher=[[Continuum International Publishing Group]] |isbn=978-0-485-11524-6 |pages=180–181 }}</ref>
